books.name: Life Lived Wild: Adventures at the Edge of the Map
books.description: Life Lived Wild: Adventures at the Edge of the Map by Rick Ridgeway is a compelling collection of the author’s most remarkable and daring adventures from a life lived on the edge of exploration and the natural world. Ridgeway, a renowned mountaineer, adventurer, and storyteller, takes readers through his expeditions to the world's most remote and challenging environments, from the Himalayas to the depths of the Amazon. This memoir captures the spirit of exploration, the allure of the unknown, and the passion for the wilderness that defines his life. In this inspiring book, Ridgeway shares his firsthand experiences of climbing, rafting, and traversing some of the most untamed landscapes on Earth, all while reflecting on the lessons learned from these wild places and the urgency of preserving them for future generations.

books.name: Salmon: A Fish, the Earth and the History of Their Common Fate
books.description: "Salmon: A Fish, the Earth and the History of Their Common Fate" by Mark Kurlansky is a deep and reflective exploration of the iconic fish that has shaped human history, ecosystems, and cultures around the world. This beautifully illustrated hardcover book explores the natural history of salmon, their vital role in ecosystems, and the cultural significance they hold in various indigenous communities and modern societies. Kurlansky weaves together scientific analysis, historical narratives, and personal accounts of the devastating impact of overfishing, environmental destruction, and climate change on salmon populations. With a unique focus on the intertwined fates of the fish and the planet, this book calls attention to the urgent need for conservation efforts and sustainable practices to protect salmon for future generations.

books.author: Glen Denny
books.description: Yosemite in the Sixties by Glen Denny is a visually stunning hardcover book that captures the golden era of climbing in Yosemite National Park during the 1960s. Through a rich collection of personal photographs, Denny chronicles the era when Yosemite became the heart of American rock climbing. The book offers rare glimpses into the lives of iconic climbers such as Royal Robbins, Warren Harding, and Yvon Chouinard, as they pushed the boundaries of what was possible on Yosemite's granite walls. Along with stunning images, Denny provides a firsthand account of the cultural shifts and pioneering spirit that defined the decade. It’s a tribute to the athletes, the place, and the time that shaped the climbing community and influenced outdoor culture as we know it today.

books.name: Cracked: The Future of Dams in a Hot, Chaotic World
books.author: Steven Hawley
books.description: Cracked: The Future of Dams in a Hot, Chaotic World by Steven Hawley examines the role of dams in the face of climate change and an increasingly volatile world. The book explores the often-unseen impact of dams on ecosystems, communities, and water resources, offering an in-depth look at how these structures—once seen as technological marvels—are now coming under scrutiny for their environmental consequences. Through extensive research and interviews, Hawley provides an informed and balanced perspective on the future of dams, proposing a necessary rethinking of their role in our increasingly unpredictable climate. The book challenges readers to consider what we can do to reshape water infrastructure for the future in a way that supports both human and environmental needs.
